Award.AwardTitle: CC*Integration: BRACELET: Robust Cloudlet Infrastructure for Scientific Instruments' Lifetime Connectivity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Universities typically have many scientific instruments in interdisciplinary
research laboratories to conduct high-quality research in science and engineering.
Yet many of these older operating instruments are prematurely disconnected from campus networks
because they cannot operate at the speed of a modern computing devices, or use legacy operating system software
that is not updated with the latest security patches, creating potential vulnerabilities.

This project will develop a robust cloudlet-based infrastructure, called BRACELET.
BRACELET is an integrated three-tier infrastructure that integrates the
existing campus network, cloud, and security infrastructures with the NSF DIBBs program supported 4CeeD
data file upload service. Each cloudlet will be placed alongside potentially vulnerable instruments to shape traffic
and protect against external threats. The cloudlet will play a crucial role in keeping the instrument connected throughout its
lifetime, continuously providing otherwise missing or new performance and security features for the
instrument. BRACELET will extend the capabilities and useful lifetime of scientific instruments, helping to accelerate
scientific innovation and discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BRACELET project, funded by the NSF OAC CC*Integration grant, is about developing a robust cloudlet-based cyberinfrastructure for sustainable access of campus-based scientific instruments to remote data management services on private cloud(s), and for enabling lifetime connectivity between cloud and aging instruments such as SEMs (Scanning Electronic Microscopes) and TEMs (Transmission Electronic Microscopes).

The problems for academic laboratories are the following: (1) Scientific instruments, being multi-million-dollar investment, age at slower pace than computing and networking software and hardware. On average, academic scientific instruments last 20-30 years, where cyber-components must be upgraded every 6 months to 2-years for security and performance reasons. (2) Scientific software, driving instruments, has usually 6-8 years warranty. (3) Scientific software is embedded inside instrument?s computer?s operating system (OS) for performance reasons. This means that every time OS is upgraded, the scientific software must upgrade.

The above problems cause a major mismatch between the scientific software upgrades, done by an instrument provider, and the OS software upgrades, done by a computing service provider. To keep the instrument?s computer securely connected to the campus network, OS must be upgraded and patched frequently. If OS is not upgraded with up-to-date patches, the instrument?s computer becomes highly vulnerable to external viruses and other external security attacks. This also means that if  OS gets upgraded, the scientific software must get upgraded. But since the scientific software gets upgraded at much slower pace, the instrument?s managers must wait with OS upgrades until instrument providers upgrade their scientific software packages. But if OS is not upgraded, the instrument is taken offline for fear of security attacks, causing the instrument user loss of any remote access to advanced data management services on clouds and data storage facilities. The offline situation leads to (a) major slow-down of research since local storage on the instrument?s computer is limited, (b) usage of memory sticks which poses security threats, and (c) loss of productivity at the scientific instrument site since researchers conduct less experiments and take less images per hour due to spending time to transform raw microscopy data into formats that would fit on memory sticks.

We have designed and implemented multiple versions of BRACELET cloudlet (edge) device and deployed the final version of BRACELET solution in MRL (Materials Research Lab), HMNTL (Holonyak Micro & Nanotechnology Lab), and other laboratories across the campus. Our initial solutions developed the edge-cloud solution based on Kubernetes and microservices. Our cloud is a private cloud, called 4CeeD, residing on the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign campus, running Clowder-based data management system. 

In Version 0, 4CeeD controlled the BRACELET device services, including the security and traffic shaping services. The 4CeeD cloud had the capability to offload the computation of some data workflow services, e.g., the metadata extraction service, into the edge device in case of a high 4ceed load. The security service provided authentication, and check of network addresses to ensure that data and control requests are coming from a valid user and a valid instrument. The traffic shaping service ensured that TCP connections between the older instrument?s computer and the cloud would not time-out.

In Version 1, we have offloaded some security functions from the BRACELET device into the network as follows: (a) We have established Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN) and put the aging instruments on the VLAN. (b) At Layer 2 VLAN switch level, we used the ?isolate-list? feature to disable any port-to-port communication which are specified in the isolate-list. This allowed us to specify the direction of data traffic from instrument ports to BRACELET device only. At Layer 3 router level, we used an outbound access control list (ACL ?allow-list?) to control what traffic is allowed to communicate between different networks. We allow only traffic from aging instruments to the BRACELET device and some essential network services like DHCP and DNS. We call the VLAN switch and router network the BRACELET network. (c)  The BRACELET device, called BRACELET server, has now interfaces to the BRACELET network and to the campus network to interconnect the instrument with campus cloud/storage facility. (d) We have simplified the Web client interface on the instrument?s side to allow user only uploading of data, but no interaction with the remote cloud.

In Version 2, we have kept the BRACELET network carefully configured for one-way traffic. Furthermore, we have simplified the BRACELET server, removing the offloading service, but leaving the security and networking services, and enabled the connectivity of the BRACELET server to other remote data management and storage facilities.

For broader impact, we have given scientific talks, published results, put the code in public github repository, included the material into lectures of the NSF NRT DIGIMAT PhD training program, and are active in the MaRDA MDI Provider Integration and Interoperability Working Group.
